did.abstract: Social Service organization serving the Detroit African American community, affiliate of the National Urban League; includes minutes of the Board of Directors, correspondence and topical files of Executive Directors and Presidents, budgets and financial records, and papers concerning National Urban League conferences and Green Pastures Camp; also departmental files relating to community services, housing, vocational services, health and welfare, job development and employment, and education and youth incentives; and photographs.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: The collection (Donor No. 4042) has been received in several accessions beginning in 1963. Periodic additions to the collection continue.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research except for boxes 35-36.

userestrict.p: Copyright to the collection has been transferred to the Regents of the University of Michigan.

altformavail.p: The 16mm films in the collection were digitized in 2009 as part of a library video preservation project. Preservation master beta tapes for all titles and high resolution digital files of some titles were created along with DVD and streaming files for all titles. The DVDs are available for use in the library. A selection of the streaming files may be available online at a given time, others can be mounted on request.

prefercite.p: item, folder title, box no., Detroit Urban League Records, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: The Detroit Urban League (hereafter referred to as the D.U.L.), an affiliate of the National Urban League (N.U.L.), was founded in 1916 to address the needs of the growing population of African-Americans in Detroit. The N.U.L. had been founded in 1910 in New York as the National League on Urban Conditions Among Negroes as an agency responsive to the needs of Black emigrants from the south who were then coming in great numbers to the urban north.

The establishment of the D.U.L. was a joint effort of the N.U.L. and the Associated Charities of Detroit. The D.U.L. was and is a problem oriented agency, creating programs and services to meet the most pressing educational, employment, health, and social needs of the Detroit African American community.

The D.U.L. was at first funded by the Associated Charities of Detroit (which later evolved into the Community Fund). It has also, in the past, received allocations from the N.U.L. In 1992, the D.U.L. received funding from the Community Fund's successor United Community Services of Detroit, the local United Way Foundation; from local, federal and state grants; and from N.U.L. grants and individual D.U.L. memberships.

The D.U.L., although it operates as an independent agency, is linked to the national organization through the N.U.L.'s "Terms of Affiliation." Policy is set by a board of directors and a strong executive director/president. The D.U.L. chief executive officers since its founding have been:

For further information on the D.U.L. records, the researcher should consult A Brief History of the Detroit Urban League and Description of the League's Papers in the Michigan Historical Collections (Michigan Historical Collections Bulletin No. 20) and the MHC's Guide to the Microfilm Edition of the Detroit Urban League Papers. These bulletins also contain references to other sources of information about the D.U.L. at the Michigan Historical Collections and elsewhere. The researcher should additionally consult the papers of John C. Dancy and Francis A. Kornegay and the records of the Children's Fund of Michigan also located at the Michigan Historical Collections. For a perspective on the D.U.L.'s Green Pastures Camp, Keri Bancroft's "Green Pastures Camp: Scene II" (Michigan History Magazine, 69, no. 5, September/October 1985, pp. 32-39) is a useful source.

A separate collection of D.U.L. materials is located at the Burton Historical Collections of the Detroit Public Library; while the records of United Community Services of Detroit are at the Wayne State University Labor Archives.

arrangement.p: The records of the Detroit Urban League have been received in a series of accessions beginning in 1963. The first four accessions, 1963-1971, were reprocessed in 1977 and have been designated "Original Accessions." Beginning in 1977, upon receipt of new materials, the decision was made to process subsequent accessions as separate units of the collection, even though they might contain materials from an earlier period. These later groupings of files are labeled "1977 Accession. Records, 1936-1977," "1985 Accession. Records, 1939-1985," and "1992 Accession. Records, 1924-1992." The four accessions with their principal series are:

scopecontent.p: The records of the Detroit Urban League include minutes of the Board of Directors, correspondence and topical files of Executive Directors and Presidents, budgets and financial records, and papers concerning National Urban League conferences and Green Pastures Camp; also departmental files relating to community services, housing, vocational services, health and welfare, job development and employment, and education and youth incentives. The records also include photographs of chapter activities, meetings, and ceremonies; photos of buildings and staff (notably executive directors, John Dancy and Francis Kornegay); also films.

scopecontent.p: Executive Directors' Files, 1916-1969 (boxes 1-36) include the general correspondence and topical files of Forrester B. Washington and John Dancy; minutes of meetings of the League's Board of Directors; budget and financial records; files concerning National Urban League. conferences and the Green Pastures Camp program. The series also includes printed pamphlets, reports, newsletters and books produced by for the Detroit Urban League and other Urban League chapters.

scopecontent.p: The Departmental Files series, 1947-1968 (boxes 37-56) consists of the records of the Community Services and Vocational Services Departments from the early 1940s to 1963 and the records of the Housing Department, the Education and Youth Incentives Department, the Health and Welfare Department, and the Job Development and Employment Department from 1964 through 1968.

scopecontent.p: In August 1977, the Michigan Historical Collections received 17 additional feet of Detroit Urban League material. This accession covers primarily the period of the 1950s and 1960s, though there is some earlier material dating as early as 1916. The newly received material was divided into two broad categories: materials created by the National Urban League or its affiliates in cities other than Detroit, and materials generated by the D.U.L. The N.U.L. material is concerned chiefly with the annual national conferences. There is also an extensive file of materials created by other Urban League affiliates.

The majority of this accession was created by the D.U.L. It includes an extensive file of minutes of both the organization's executive board and of other various staff meetings, as well as an extensive file of reports. There is additionally a reference file, interoffice material, correspondence, printed matter and information relating to Green Pastures Camp

scopecontent.p: In the summer of 1985, the Detroit Urban League added materials to its holdings at the Michigan Historical Collections. These materials, comprising thirteen linear feet of records, document the later 1960s and the 1970s, although there are some materials dating as early as 1926. The materials are especially strong in documenting the activities of the D.U.L. in the early 1970s. They have not been interfiled with earlier records. Thus, there may be considerable overlap with documents arranged in the earlier accessions.

Material from the 1985 accession is divided into three subgroups to parallel the tenure of the executive directors: John C. Dancy, 1918-1960; Francis A. Kornegay, 1960-1978; and Roy L[evy] Williams, 1978-1984. Within the three subgroups, materials have been arranged according to office of creation within the D.U.L. hierarchy: Executive Board, Executive Director (changed to President in 1978), Assistant (Deputy) Director, and Departments (Committees during Dancy's tenure) arranged alphabetically. Within these series, the materials are first arranged according to type and then chronologically. They include correspondence, minutes, reports, memoranda, and topical files created by the D.U.L. The best sources to gain a sense of D.U.L. activity are the executive board minutes; the richest sources on the condition of Blacks in Detroit are the various departmental research reports.

scopecontent.p: In the course of processing this accession, the photographs from previous accessions have been reprocessed. All photos are now found in box 87. They are arranged, as much as possible, to accord with the organizing scheme laid out for the 1985 accession. That is, photos are linked to Executive Directors (Dancy and Kornegay) and to Departments (Education, Employment, Health, and Social Services). The Celebrations/Dinners, Guild, Green Pastures Camp, and individuals' photos lie outside this scheme. The small number of photographs from the 1992 accession have also been added to the photograph series in box 87.

did.unittitle: In School Street School Program circa 1982-1986 (and later?)
Individuals (includes Board of Directors and Award winners) 1940s-1970s

scopecontent.p: The Films series consists of several brief (15 to 30 second) clips and one film produced in cooperation with National Bank of Detroit title "The Bank is Open to You" which explores opportunities for African Americans in the banking industry. The film as been digitized and is available on DVD in the library or a flash streaming video on request.

did.unittitle: NBD's "The Bank is Open to You" 1965

scopecontent.p: 1992 accession of 9 linear feet of records documents principally the activities of the Detroit Urban League in the 1980s. There is, however, significant material from the 1970s and a small amount from the 1960s and earlier. The 1992 accession of the Detroit Urban League materials is divided into five series: the Executive Director's/President's file, 1961-1992; the Deputy Director's file, 1968-1978; Staff Files, 1978-1992; and Printed Material, 1974-1991. It must be noted that very few sequences in this accession are complete.

The Executive Director's/President's file is continued from earlier accessions. Due to a change in the organizational structure in 1978, the title of executive director was now changed to president. There are five sub-series in this series: Executive Director Francis A. Kornegay, 1960-1978; President Roy Levy Williams, 1978-1984; Interim President Sue Hamilton-Smith, 1984-1985; President Donald W. Woods, 1985-1987; and President N. Charles Anderson, 1987- .

The Kornegay subseries is relatively small (the majority of his papers and records are found in earlier D.U.L. accessions and in the Francis A. Kornegay collection), mostly reflecting his later years as Executive Director. However, there are some materials from the early 1960s, including information on the Religious Resources Committee (1962-1963). Of particular interest in this sequence are the records from the Public Issues Task Force.

scopecontent.p: The Roy Levy Williams subseries represents the core of the president's file. Adding and rejuvenating programs, Williams continued the work of the League. He increased the scope of membership drives, created the Blue Monday Network of young minority professionals as mentors, and created the Distinguished Warriors Annual Award Dinner (at first calling it the Old Warriors Award).

scopecontent.p: The Sue Hamilton-Smith subseries, though small in size, complements the records she created while she was Executive Assistant to the President and Vice-President for External Affairs. Hamilton-Smith served as Interim President of the D.U.L. during the search which resulted in Donald W. Woods becoming president of the D.U.L.

did.unittitle: Child Abuse Prevention Federal Challenge Grants Program 1985
Community Development and Economic Development Committee 1985

scopecontent.p: Woods served only two years as president of the D.U.L. His small collection of papers displays his relationship with the D.U.L. Board of Directors, his emphasis on work with young urban people and his drive to increase the League's membership and profile in the Detroit community.

did.unittitle: Press Release: The D.U.L. Supports School Based Clinics 1986
The State of Black Michigan: 1985. -- Clippings 1985

scopecontent.p: N. Charles Anderson's series contains information about the N.U.L. convention in Detroit in 1988. In 1992, Anderson continues his work at the Urban League.

did.unittitle: National Urban League Convention -- The Michigan Chronicle July 30, 1988

scopecontent.p: Winston Lang, a social worker, came to work for the D.U.L. in the late 1960s. He soon became Deputy Director, Kornegay's assistant (in 1970). This material chiefly contains budget and funding records from 1968-1978 and correspondence. Although there are similar folders in earlier accessions, there is very little duplication of information in this series.

did.unittitle: "Confidentiality of Information Obtained from Clients." circa 1971

scopecontent.p: The staff files series contains four subseries created by officers of the Urban League: Sue Hamilton-Smith, 1978-1984; Barbara Rennie, 1982-1988 and 1974-87; Annette Seaborn, 1985-1988; and Jo-Anne Woodard, 1985-1988. The subseries of the staff files are arranged chronologically by the date when an individual began working at the D.U.L. With the exception of Barbara Rennie's Report File, 1974-1987, which is a chronological file, all of these subseries are alphabetically arranged topical files.

Sue Hamilton-Smith came in 1979 to work for the Urban League. She had previously served on its Public Issues Task Force and had worked with Williams when he was an assistant to Governor Milliken. The Sue Hamilton-Smith subseries contains material on League programs during her tenure as Executive Assistant to the President and Vice-President for External Affairs.

did.unittitle: Albert Kahn House -- Application for National Register of Historic Places 1972-1975
"Jobless Inner City Youth vs. The Rest of America: The Birth of a Separate Values System" 1981

scopecontent.p: Barbara Rennie was a research specialist for the D.U.L., collecting and conducting research on urban populations, especially in Detroit. Rennie also wrote position and research papers for the D.U.L. Additionally, she was responsible for statistical reports to the Board of Directors and United Community Services of Detroit. She worked to improve and restructure the D.U.L.'s relationship with the United Way (formerly the United Foundation) and United Community Services of Detroit by submitting statistically correct reports on time and properly formatted to the agencies.

scopecontent.p: Annette Seaborn began working for the D.U.L. in 1979. Seaborn has had several titles during her tenure at the League; however, she has always served in a professional capacity, directing services and programs. This subseries reflects her work at the D.U.L. in the late 1980s. It also reflects the work of Donald West who came to the D.U.L. as a program director in the late 1980s.

scopecontent.p: Jo-Anne Woodard became director of Community Services at the Urban League in the mid-late 1980s. The monthly and service reports by Woodard in this subseries are the best source of information about the D.U.L.'s Community Services program in the late 1980s.

scopecontent.p: The Printed series contains D.U.L. periodicals and publications, arranged chronologically. As noted previously, it is not a complete sequence. This series also contains the blueprints for the restoration of the Albert Kahn House. Other material on the preservation and conservation of the Albert Kahn House can be found in the Sue Hamilton-Smith and Barbara Rennie subseries.

did.unittitle: Albert Kahn House -- Preservation and Conservation -- Blueprints 1986
